children.value: Parses a glTF file. Can load both the
A glTF file contains a hierarchical scenegraph description that can be used to instantiate corresponding hierarcy of actual
related classes in most WebGL libraries.
aims to take care of as much processing as possible, while remaining framework-independent.
The GLTF Loader returns an object with a
field containing the glTF Scenegraph. In its basic mode, the
does not modify the loaded JSON in any way. Instead, the results of additional processing are placed in parallel top-level fields such as
. This ensures that applications that want to work with the standard glTF data structure can do so.
Optionally, the loaded gltf can be "post processed", which lightly annotates and transforms the loaded JSON structure to make it easier to use. Refer to

In addition, certain glTF extensions, in particular Draco mesh encoding, can be fully or partially processed during loading. When possible (and extension processing is enabled), such extensions will be resolved/decompressed and replaced with standards conformant representations. See
Note: while supported, synchronous parsing of glTF (e.g. using
) has significant limitations. When parsed asynchronously (using
), the following additional capabilities are enabled:
linked binary resource URI:s will be loaded and resolved (assuming a valid base url is available).
base64 encoded binary URI:s inside the JSON payload will be decoded.
linked image URI:s can be loaded and decoded.
Draco meshes can be decoded asynchronously on worker threads (in parallel!).
Fetch any referenced image files (and decode base64 encoded URIS). Async only.
Decompress Draco compressed meshes (if DracoLoader available).
Perform additional post processing on the loaded glTF data.
that transforms parts of JSON structure in the loaded glTF data, to make glTF data easier use in applications and WebGL libraries, however this changes the format of the data returned by the
(the default),the parsed JSON chunk will be returned, and
will have been performed, which will link data from binary buffers into the parsed JSON structure using non-standard fields, and also modify the data in other ways to make it easier to use.
At the top level, this will look like a standard glTF JSON structure:
However, the objects inside these arrays will have been pre-processed to simplify usage. For details on changes and extra fields added to the various glTF objects, see
, an unprocessed glTF/GLB data structure will be returned, with binary buffers provided as an
// The base URI used to load this glTF, if any. For resolving relative uris to linked resources.
// Containse the parsed glTF JSON or the parsed GLB JSON chunk
// Length and indices of this array will match `json.buffers`
// The GLB bin chunk, if present, will be found in buffer 0.
// Additional glTF json `buffers` are fetched and base64 decoded from the JSON uri:s.
// Images can optionally be loaded and decoded, they will be stored here
// Length and indices of this array will match `json.buffers`
// GLBLoader output, if this was a GLB encoded glTF
| length of GLB (e.g. embedded in larger binary block)
Parsed JSON from the JSON chunk
offset of buffer (embedded in larger binary block)
length of buffer (embedded in larger binary block)
The output of the GLBLoader if the parsed file was GLB formatted
